newsitem.title: ARGENTINA: Argentina to issue $2.0 bln Bonte treasury bond.
newsitem.headline: Argentina to issue $2.0 bln Bonte treasury bond.

text.p: Argentina's Undersecretary of Finance Miguel Kiguel said Monday the country is planning to introduce a $2.0 billion Bonte treasury bond.
The bond will be sold in tranches, with the first auction, of $500, due May 6. Subsequent tranches will be sold through auctions later in the year.
Kiguel also said Argentina is expecting to issue a bond denominated in yen during the second quarter, equivalent to about $400 million.
Additionally, the undersecretary said bonds in pesetas amounting to between $80 million and $100 million will be issued before the end of this month.

"This (the Bonte bond) will change our financing strategy a little. Firstly, because it is the first long bond that will be issued through the market-maker system and because it is a long bond of five years," Kiguel told journalists.
The longest Bonte currently outstanding is two years.
Kiguel said he had met with market-makers and agreed on the five-year issue. After the auction of the first tranche, he will meet again with the market-makers to agree on subsequent auction dates.
Introducing a five-year bonte is part of the Economy Ministry's financing strategy of lengthening the maturity of its debt portfolio and building up the local market.
"We will be creating a very liquid local bond with this issue," Kiguel said.
Apart from the Bonte issue, he said the ministry had no plans of issuing in the dollar sector in the second quarter.
Kiguel said Argentina is also considering an issue in Italian lire. Within 15 days a decision will be made on whether a lira issue will be placed.

Turning to the recent upgrade of Argentina's credit rating by Standard & Poor's to BB from BB-, Kiguel said: "Argentina has all the economic indicators to be investment grade. With luck we could be investment grade within two years -- I would say between two and five years we will be investment grade."
BB is two grades below investment-grade.

Kiguel added that some $3.4 billion of debt remained to be raised in the international markets through the year and $2.5 billion in the local market. Of the $2.5 billion, $2.0 billion will be covered by the new Bonte and $500 million by a Letes Treasury bill issue, probably in October.
